docs.snippet: Four men accused of assassinating Lebanese statesman Rafik al-Hariri used dozens of mobile phones during the last weeks of his life to coordinate the massive car bombing that killed him and 21 others in 2005, prosecutors said on Thursday....

docs.snippet: A measure making it a crime to call someone a Nazi battles the trivialization of an atrocity, but not everyone agrees that this is the way to proceed....
docs.lead_paragraph: A measure making it a crime to call someone a Nazi battles the trivialization of an atrocity, but not everyone agrees that this is the way to proceed.
docs.abstract: Israel's Parliament gives preliminary approval to measure that would make it a crime to call someone a Nazi, or any other slur associated with Third Reich; backers say proposed law is response to rising tide of anti-Semitism, but critics believe it is dangerous infringement on free speech and an overreach impossible to enforce.

headline.main: Israel’s Efforts to Limit Use of Holocaust Terms Raise Free-Speech Questions
headline.print_headline: Israel’s Efforts to Limit Use of Holocaust Terms Raise Free-Speech Questions

byline.contributor: Hannah Olivennes and Bernadette Murphy contributed research from Paris, and Lucy Jordan from Brasília.
